div.p: CCCC MS 162 is a collection of Old English homiles, written in the early eleventh century. Its spellings, and similiarities with the script and decoration of Oxford, Bodleian Library, MSS Bodley 340 and 342 and London, BL MS Royal 6. C. I, suggest that it originated somewhere in the south-east of England, perhaps at Rochester or Canterbury. The texts it contains are mostly by Ælfric, but it also includes some anonymous material, including sermons for Thursday, Friday and Saturday of Holy Week, for which Ælfric refused to provide sermon material. Parker removed some material from CCCC MS 178, a Worcester book, into MS 162, where it is now pp. 139-60. He also added a woodcut of the Crucifixion at the front of the manuscript.
